title: The golem framework
text:
The golem is an ‘opinionated’ Shiny framework that provides many options for users who are experienced with package development, but who are looking to streamline application development.

library(golem)



_apps/gap
├── CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
├── DESCRIPTION
├── LICENSE
├── LICENSE.md
├── NAMESPACE
├── R
├── README.Rmd
├── README.md
├── app.R
├── codecov.yml
├── data
├── data-raw
├── dev
├── gap.Rproj
├── inst
├── man
├── tests
└── vignettes




Below is the namespace file for gap.
# Generated by roxygen2: do not edit by hand

export(run_app)
import(shiny)
importFrom(rlang,.data)
As you can see, I’m only exporting the run_app() function from gap.



The Imports field in the DESCRIPTION file lists the following:
Imports: 
    config (>= 0.3.1),
    ggplot2,
    golem (>= 0.3.5),
    rlang,
    shiny (>= 1.7.4),
    stringr,
    tools
The graph in the application uses ggplot2, rlang, and tools. golem is importing config (and itself).

title: Shiny Frameworks
text:
This repo contains the following shiny applications:

gap: a golem app-package
lap: a leprechaun app-package
rap: a rhino app (pseudo-package)
duap: a devtools/usethis app-package



One of the constant concerns for developers is relying on an experimental or ‘new’ add-on package, that code changing, and something we built that used to work is now breaking.
All shiny app-packages depend on shiny and devtools, so adding more dependencies can make developers uneasy.
